inlineContent.text: The QuantActions SDK for iOS allows developers to add all the QuantActions functions to an iOS app including:
Automatic data collection
Access processed metrics and insights from the Tap Intelligence Engine (TIE)
Enabling device communication
Subscribe to different cohorts
The SDK can be added to the main app, the keyboard extension and other targets if needed.
QuantActions SDK can be installed with the Swift Package Manager:
To start using the SDK you will need an API key provided by QuantActions. If you have not yet received your API key please
Add API key to the Info.plist file of your app. If file is not visible in Project Navigator, select your app’s target > Info and add new key/value pair.
The QuantActions SDK does most of the keyboard related work under the hood, but it’s still necessary to add the keyboard extension to your app in Xcode.
Select your Project in the Project Navigator,
Navigate to File > New > Target,
Select the Custom Keyboard Extension from the Application Extension group and click next,
Specify a Product Name and click finish.
Select keyboard extension target > General Pane > Frameworks and Libraries -> Click “+” button and select QASwiftSDK.
Locate your Custom Keyboard Extension in the Project Navigatior and modify KeyboardViewController class by replacing its content with:
The SDK doesn’t support building with bitcode so it must be disabled to avoid compilation failures.
Select your Custom Keyboard Extension’s General Pane > Build Settings,
Under the Build Options find the option Enable Bitcode and set it to No.
Navigate to Custom Keyboard Extension’s General Pane > Info > NSExtension,
Under NSExtensionAttributes, find RequestsOpenAccess key of type Boolean and set its value to 1.

CoreMotion - to collect

HealthKit - to collect
To make these functions work properly, it’s necessary to perform several steps:
Add
key to the plist file describing why your app uses motion data.
Add
and
to the plist file describing why your app uses sleep data. Also, it’s necessary to add these keys to keyboard extension.
Add HealthKit capability to your app’s target and keyboard extension. See
for more information.

Note: Xcode might ask for adding new entitlements file. If you have entitlements file already created, add HealthKit entitlements to already existing file instead of creating new one (allow Xcode to create a new file if asked, copy the entitlements to the old file and remove the new one created by Xcode).
Ask user for permissions from within your app. Data collection won’t work without authorization. For that purpose you can use SDK’s helper functions/properties:
- requests CoreMotion permissions by displaying system alert;
- requests HealthKit permissions by displaying system popup;
- returns CoreMotion authorization status (
- indicates whether a user was already asked for HealthKit permissions required by the SDK. HealthKit doesn’t allow to determine whether a user has granted permissions or not;
Each keyboard extension may have a different bundle identifier. In order to make QuantActions SDK able to determine keyboard’s state, it’s necessary to pass your keyboard’s bundle id to the SDK via
field set in Info.plist file of your app.
It’s possible to replace default image displayed on the keyboard (top left corner) by overriding the
field in
. For example:

The QuantActions Keyboard extension might collect data and send server requests under the hood even when the app is killed. In order to share storage between the SDK, your app and keyboard extension, it’s necessary to configure App Group within your app’s Capabilities. See
for more information.
Configure your app and keybaord extension to use the same App Group.
After adding the same App Group to an app and the keyboard extension, add the name of the App Group to the Info.plist file of your app using
key:
QuantActions uses Firebase Messaging. First of all, it’s necessary to setup a Firebase Cloud Messaging in your project.
for more information.
In order to allow QuantActions server to send push notification to the device, remember to use
for updating push notifications token in the SDK. Mostly, it might looks like this:

code: func messaging(_ messaging: Messaging, didReceiveRegistrationToken fcmToken: String?) {

Before using any features, the QA SDK needs to be initialized. To do so you will need an API key provided by QuantActions. If you have not yet received your API key please
Add API key to your Info.plist as mentioned in the

To track a device it is necessary to subscribe the device to a cohort. Each device can be subscribed in two ways. For a cohort with a known number of devices to track, QuantActions provides a set of codes (subscription / participation IDs) of the form

that have to be distributed. The way the code is entered into the app is the choice of the developer. In our TapCounter R&D app we use both a copy&paste method and a QR code scanning method, once the code as been acquired the device can then be registered using the SDK.

code: let subscription = try await QA.shared.subscribe(participationID: subscriptionID)

inlineContent.text: For cohorts where the number of participants is unknown the SDK can be used to register the device by simply using the cohortId provided by QA (this way needs special access so make sure you are authorized by QuantActions to use this functionality).

code: let subscription = try await QA.shared.subscribe(participationID: cohortID)

inlineContent.text: Note that multiple devices can be subscribed using the same
, this is the case when a user has multiple devices or changes device (e.g. old phone is broken). The data from multiple devices sharing the same
will be merged to generate insights and metric, thus the same
should not be used for different users. When subscribing the device using a general
, get device gets automatically assigned a
, to retrieve this id and use it to register other devices use the following code.

While the data collection and synchronization is automated within the SDK. Retrieval of metrics and insights has to be done manually within the app in order to access only the subset of metrics and trends that the application needs.
There are the following methods for retrieving different kind of Metrics:
Action Speed Metric:
Typing Speed Metric:
Congitive Fitness Metric:
Social Engagement Metric:
Social Taps Metric:
Screen Time Aggregate Metric:
Sleep Score Metric
Sleep Summary Metric
There is the following method for retrieving Trends based on the given kind of trend:
Date Interval

Although we do not recommend it, the data collection can be paused/resumed via methods offered by the QA shared instance:
You can also check the data collection running state by using
property.
The SDK allows also to use a journaling function to log a series of entries. Each entry is composed of:
A date
A small text describing the entry
A list of events (from a predefined pool)
A rating (1 to 5) for each event in the entry
The predefined
s can be retrieved with
. With that adding an entry is done by using
Entries can also be deleted:
The full journal (all entries) can be retrieved with
Feel free to use the issue tracking of this repo to report any problem with the SDK, in case of more immediate assistance need feel free to contact us at

only a set of predefined event kinds can be assigned to a journal event.

The first time you use the QA SDK in the code you should initialize it, this allows the SDK to create a unique
identifier and initiate server transactions and workflows. Most of the functionality will not work if you have never
initialized the singleton before.
This data struct hold detailed information about a sleep session (or sleep episode).
Data struct containing all the information about the trend.
Use this function to update the basic info of a user.

This is the main element used to access all the functionality of the QA SDK.
As a singleton it can be called easily from anywhere in the code and gives access to all the possible interactions with the QA backend, as well as some functions to retrieve user metrics.
Project version number for QuantActionsSDK.
Holds the information about the current subscription. It returns the
subscription ID, the list of device IDs connected to this subscription and the cohort ID relative to
the subscription.
Allows to get all journal entries created so far.
Retrieves the
items that can be used while logging journal entries.
The events come from a fixed set which may be updated in the future.
Struct representing errors that may occur within the SDK.
Retrieves Typing Speed metric.
Requests permission to read CoreMotion (Motion Activity) data requiered by the SDK.
When subscribing to a cohort with a cohort ID or a subscription ID, the call will return a model
which contains all information related to the cohort including necessary
permissions and privacy policy.
Ready to use SwiftUI view for presenting the keyboard language settings.
This view uses
under the hood so it’s recommended to present it modally (eg. sheet, fullScreenCover).
Basic demographic information of the user associated with the device.
